Insights: Cognitive Science is such a fascinating field because of its interdisciplinary yet cohesive nature. Thanks to the fact that the question "how does the mind work?" is inherently one that needs to be addressed at different levels, one really gets to see how different (sub)fields inform AND (constructively) constrain each other.

This course was extremely poorly structured. Starting from the macro level, it was divided into topics that were interesting to the professor and not necessarily relevant to the topic. For instance, we spent 3 classes on decision making/reasoning/perception and generally learned the same things twice because that is the research topic that my professor is most interested in. Instead we could have spent 1 lesson on it and learned some cool topic more in depth like olfaction, or music. Then looking at individual lessons, the slides were very poorly structured: Prof Scholl would present an idea, then move on, then go back to that idea without properly connecting or explaining that he was going back. A lot of the class was bullshit ideas like modularity, and professor Scholl took a very polarized role on fMRI and neuroimaging studies saying they are pretty much irrelevant, which is not representative of the scientific community. In addition the class was in the art gallery basement which was dark and poorly lit, so in addition to the poor teaching and bad lighting and time of the course, every person I spoke to in the class would fall asleep. Additionally, I went to a lot of review sessions and office hours for both the professor as well as several teaching fellows, and due to the poor structure, lack of resources (no textbook or outline of some sort),  I was constantly left confused and unsatisfied with my questions. Additionally there was no help we were given to study for the tests except for significantly reduced class notes that made no sense, making it very stressful and unpleasant studying for the exams. In addition, many topics such as linguistics, Professor Scholl taught way too fast and with too much depth and so it was completely not understandable and he taught it in a confusing manner. Instead if he focused on a smaller breadth of details but focused more time on each one, I would get significantly more out of this course.

It would be cool if major themes of the course (instinct blindness, for example) were introduced at the beginning of each lecture. Sometimes I wasn't really sure what the point of a particular experiment was; sure, I could tell you what the experimenters concluded (individuals miss the yellow dot during the MIB experiment), but I couldn't tell you why it occurred, or what it meant in the broader scope of cognitive science. I wish Professor Scholl would emphasize the take-home point much more clearly after each example (like in big bright red letters or something: "This experiment is an example of _______"). This course would really benefit from biweekly review sessions led by a couple of TF's that went over confusing material. It is very tempting to not review notes until right before the exam.

There is just way too much anecdotal examples and studies with insufficient sample size to be convincing. For most of the time, I did not believe the studies. But it's a fun gut overall.

I was often frustrated at how little information we had access to after lecture. I understand that the point is to make student feel like they are losing something if they dont come to class, but I never missed a lecture and still struggled with this.
I feel that more feedback throughout the semester wouldve been really helpful. I understand why it may be difficult with a class this size.
Strength is fun and engaging lectures, but it can be unorganized and difficult to know which material could be tested on. The content is pretty mind-blowing and almost unbelievable.

Strengths: interesting and mindblowing; concepts are manageable if you put the time and effort in to really understand them; Professor Scholl is great at keeping the information succinct and comprehensible; everything on the exam is information that was taught (no random curveballs); excellent TF's who were extremely helpful and knowledgeable

Weaknesses: often times hard to keep up in lecture because Professor Scholl does not have many notes on the slides; the classroom situation this semester was a bit concerning with low lighting and no desks

The strengths of the course was it's use of a variety of contemporary sources which made the field feel alive. Weaknesses were despite the long emails instructions were often unclear. The grading on exams was very nit picky, valuing specific verbiage over understanding. The questions also presented a significant gap from what was taught in lecture. The professor often taught the lectures at a whirlwind pace spending more time on examples rather than discussing content. The paper was similiarly hard to divine what was expected.

We covered a lot in a short period of time, and I feel that we gained comfort and familiarity with a variety of diverse topics. I wish we had been able to dive a little bit more in depth into the topics briefly touched upon in the last lecture.

Every lecture in this course was incredibly engaging and though provoking. I thought  the readings were fascinating as well and the reading responses were relevant and interesting to think about and complete. The TAs and Professor Scholl were always available for extra help and support throughout the course. The course, however, I believe could be improved by having more resources available if one wants to review material post-lecture--especially a term the one may have missed the explanation of or not heard be defined in the lecture. More detailed slides, or slides with more writing/notes on them, could possibly be a way to provide more review materials.

The organization of the course was all over the place and part of that is the topics covered and aim of a survey course, but the lecture slides online were confusing and the feedback from Tas and ability to improve throughout the year was not organized well at all.

Strengths: the professor, TF dynamic, and content presented in a compelling way
Weaknessess: The size of the class (too big)

A good structure and great lectures. All class periods were very engaging and informative. I sometimes felt that the reading questions were a little disconnected from lecture material. It would be great if the questions tested us on specific concepts covered in lecture as well. Then there would have been a way to practice applying the concepts covered in the lectures.

The main strength of this course was its wide variety of topics that made sure everyone was interested in at least one aspect of the course. The thing that prohibited me from doing better in this course was the very vague slides that were posted to the class website. I recognize this as a way to keep people coming to class, however, I am an athlete and thus missed many classes and found it hard to interpret the notes from the website.

I like the course structure in general in how it moves from general principles to specific areas to facilitate my studying. But I do think that the material in each area can be deeper and more specific.

Strengths: besides the multitude of fascinating findings, one thing I really appreciated was how much emphasis Prof. Scholl placed on helping us form a good understanding of the structure of cognitive science as a field. There are recurrent themes throughout the course, and I felt like I came out of the class with a better understanding of what science is about, what science is after and what science is/can be for. Prof. Scholl is also an incredibly engaging and passionate lecturer with amazing eloquence and a charming humor. The exams (especially the midterm) focused on testing our understanding of the material as opposed to mere memorization of facts, which made them fun to complete :D

Weaknesses: I personally did not struggle too much with making connections across the topics presented because of an overarching interest in learning about how the field works and an anchoring entry point that helped me stay grounded, but I could imagine how the breadth of the course could feel overwhelming or even disorienting if one wasn't putting in the effort to engage with the material in a proactive way.

One key strength of this course is the variety in its readings. Having to engage with actual scientific reports, philosophical essays, and news articles gave a richness of perspectives on the subject that could not be replicated in a textbook. It also gave a sense of authenticity to the learning process - that the way in which we were learning imitates (as closely as possible for an intro-level course) what it is like to study cognitive science in practice.

I thought this was a fantastic course. The things I didn't like about it had nothing to do with the structural organization but were all centered around the specific topics within cognitive science that I was not particularly interested in as an individual. The class itself, for a cognitive science class, was great.

Each lecture felt like a TED talk; the information that was taught was incredibly fascinating and presented in a way that left your mind blown. However, I believe this class would appeal more to students who are auditory learners. Often times the class was unstructured, and it felt like sometimes he went by certain slides/key points too quickly. When looking back at the slides from certain lectures, I was often confused as to what point the professor was trying to make. After the midterm, however, you start to realize what you should take notes on and what is just some random, fun trivia about our cognition.

Strengths: interesting demonstrations, terrific TFs, Brian is passionate and very knowledgeable about the subject, cool guest lecturers 

Weaknesses: the PPT slides are very poorly organized for note taking, the lectures are often more like ted talks than lessons (which makes them interesting but they often lack cohesion)

The course was very interesting as a whole, but it was difficult to know how well I understood the material until the assessments. It would have been helpful to get feedback on the reading responses to know if the ideas were correct.
I think there should be a discussion section for the class.

The court is an interesting survey of the many aspects of cognitive science - every lecture felt like a TED talk. I liked how even though the course was a large lecture, we still did engaging demonstrations and activities. The material is quite interesting as well and the workload was pretty light (short reading responses, a 7-8 page paper, and an in-class midterm/final). Sometimes, though, the professor would try too hard to make the lectures funny so I would not always be able to follow the lecture. The TFs also did not always know the answers to some of the questions raised in office hours or review sessions.

Brian Scholl did a good job of introducing the major themes of Cognitive Science; however, he did so very one-sidedly (counterarguments were brought up for only a single concept and he focused on what he personally thinks is interesting... like bees). It is a great course but very much marked by Professor Scholl's lecture style and personality. Not a bad thing but also not everyone's cup of tea, considering it is an intro course to a field many students haven't been exposed to before college. Beware, the midterm is difficult, and you have to write lecture notes nearly verbatim to study properly because the lecture slides he posts are virtually useless (over half of them are blank) and correct answers in the exams are very much restating what Professor Scholl said in lecture + what overarching themes those concepts connect to.
Having little feedback other than test grades was the classes biggest weakness.

The class was always engaging. There were never any moments where I was unable to understand what was going on. I think that I would have enjoyed getting access to more information and studies revolving a lot of the themes we poke about in class; however, this would be the only weakness.

As a survey course, this course successfully gave a taste of each segment of cognitive science. Determining each segment's relevance sometimes took a bit more insight, but this really demonstrates how interdisciplinary the field is. Dedicating large portions of class to mastering certain rudimentary skills, like solving Turing machines or case assignment, just to get a single concept across felt tedious at times. This is a nitpicky critique as most lectures were very engaging and I regularly left class amazed and enlightened.

The strength is how fascinating the units are. The weakness is that you just get a taste of a million different things. Each lecture is like a TED talk. You walk out of class thinking, "wow...it's cool that the mind does that," but then for the tests you have to know random facts about each unique TED talk.
Brian Scholl teaches the class very well and uses specific studies to showcase the concepts of the class. He assigns great readings for the class that often entail reading study reports.

Strength: interesting material
Weakness: Very disorganized, did not receive paper before the final.
The course had amazing lectures and the course content was very engaging. Really liked the work distribution. Really couldn't say for any negatives

The course covers a lot of exciting topics but sometimes suffers from a lack of central development -- that is, the classes don't build on each other in any meaningful way, which makes it easy to lose interest in the subject matter and the class as a whole. I don't know that there's any way to rectify this, because the lectures are individually very stimulating, but the course overall lacks any real cohesiveness, causing it to sometimes lose momentum and interest.

The lectures are awesome, each one is like a TED talk. The reading responses due at the beginning of every class are a bit annoying but manageable. I didn't like that it was so difficult to get feedback on my midterm, paper, and final. Also, it was difficult to study for the exam because of the content of the lecture slides and a lack of a textbook (although the TA's were very helpful in review sessions)

I think that if slides are going to be put up online then they shouldn't be blank. That was a little frustrating when going to study. I also do not think that one 2pt question on the exam should be the difference between an 82 and a 90 on the midterm especially when questions are admittedly designs to trick students.

I felt that the course's only weakness was the volume of students in the class. I feel that a discussion section would have been helpful and much appreciated by students who hope to pursue cognitive science.

You learn a lot of interesting facts from this course. I told friends that the reason I got hooked into taking this course was that the class was like a TED talk on the mind/brain for an hour twice a week. The facts are fascinating, but the course doesn't give a lot of structure for in depth thinking about the course which makes it hard to figure out how to study for the tests.

Strengths: fun and engaging lecture, no textbooks but rather scientific papers, cool auditorium
Weaknesses: it feels like we're memorizing a bunch of fun facts, no insight to exam structure before exam, hard to determine what information is important to attend to

The curve in this course is generous, but the professor makes it unnecessarily difficult to do well on the paper and the exams. You don't get any study guide, topics to focus on, exam structure, sample questions or anything to help prepare for the exams other than "if I've talked about it a lot, it's probably going to be on there!" Which is fine, you just have to study everything from all the lectures and readings, but the questions are often asked in a way that if you asked the wrong question about the topic (or whatever it might be) while studying, you're likely to get it wrong. Additionally, the paper is just a "thought" paper, in that you are supposed to come up with a new, interesting thought that's not too obvious about the field of cognitive science. There is also no rubric or anything given to give you an idea of how it will be graded. I especially think that this assignment needs to be reconsidered as cognitive science emerges more and more into mainstream discussions, because the number of new, original thoughts is certainly decreasing. The TFs are nice and helpful, but its difficult when some of them have upwards of 50 students. All in all, this is definitely the type of course that's worth potentially credit/d'ing, as you get exposed to a lot of super cool and interesting information and studies, and if you need it for your major just beware that it will take a lot more time and studying than you might expect. 

One way the course could be improved would be the paper. It would have been great if students could pick from two assignments, or perhaps write a paper responding to one of the reading responses in more depth  the reading responses were often meant to get students thinking in new, creative, and personalized ways about the material we were engaging with, so offering the opportunity for students to write their paper responding in more depth to one of the questions could have been great and would have made the paper feel more exciting for students, but also a little bit more tangible (especially if you come from a stem background, like me).

The lectures are very interesting, almost without exception. They're like cool lil' TED talk videos you come across on a YouTube binge. At the end of every lecture you'll know something cool about cognition - he's been teaching this class since forever so he's got the content and presentation nailed. Lectures are fun and engaging, and the minimal homework (reading some paper or article and answering a quick question) shouldn't take too long (although I've heard some TAs are pretty anal about the content of said responses. mine never returned any responses to my (thanks Cameron) but a friend had every other response returned with an "I think you should've included ...." TAs that do this need to chill.)

However, assessments are pretty difficult to prepare for. There is so much content given in class that you can't be sure what will be on the exam. The exams, however, themselves aren't super difficult - very few "gotcha" questions asking about specific reading/lecture details, save for details that were explained for a good amount of time. A pretty good rule of thumb is the more he talks about it, the higher the likelihood that it will be on the exams. The TAs aren't very helpful in guiding you towards what to study, but they're pretty great about explaining any specific questions you have during office hours or exam prep sessions. You honestly just kinda have to go through the first exam and experience it for yourself to make your own strategy for the final, which leaves your grade on the first exam mostly up to luck.

There's also a 5-6 page paper. That's vague, but not as vague as Scholl is on the actual assignment, which can be to or against your benefit. He calls it a "thought paper" and provides a couple examples of high-scoring papers which are all incredibly different from each other. GO TO YOUR TA (OR A DIFFERENT TA IF YOURS SUCKS) AND ASK FOR HELP WRITING IT. Think about something interesting you learned in class and go to them with that and ask them to help guide you in writing your paper; they're the ones that grade it, so follow their advice. Papers range from very academic to very colloquial and fun (I wrote a guide on how to con people using cogsci), and I assume this is mostly due to what each TA prefers. Like the exams, the paper can either suck or be fine, and it's all up to who you get assigned to.

Overall a fun class, or maybe not, depending on your luck.

Strengths: Prof Scholl is a really good lecturer. He also has a lot of interactive activities written into the lectures so the students can feel more involved. 

Weaknesses: It's a large lecture so you can't really discuss the things that you learn. Feedback was also not very clear for each student bc each TA had so many students to take care of.
the grading is way too harsh, but the lectures are very interesting
There are no practice exams, which makes it hard to prepare.

Strengths- Our daily readings gave us exposure to real, scientific writing, rather than a textbook. The professor is engaging and is able to introduce  a plethora of topics to students.

Weaknesses- Because the class covers such a wide breadth of disciplines/ideas, it can be difficult to grasp all key concepts at a fast pace. At times, more time is needed to break down these concepts for better understanding. It can also be difficult to see the relations between topics introduced in class; a greater emphasis on this could possibly facilitate better understanding.

It is a broad course that piques the interest of any student and spurs them to take more classes in cognitive science. Being an introductory course, it does not go in depth with the course material and therefore some concepts may remain quite obscure after the lecture. The professor and TFs are however here to carry on any discussion a student may have following the lecture. It is greatly entertaining and interesting to learn the course material.

A great weakness is how unrelated all of the subjects are. It's clear that cognitive science covers a lot of different areas, but if it's a major, the intro class could have better structure. It makes it difficult to study for the midterm and final. Brian Scholl is a strength and a weakness of the course - he knows a lot and is very entertaining, but he's kind of an asshole. Finally, the readings should be emphasized more - there could be more reading questions so you have to read all of it.

I found every lecture to be very engaging, and it was very easy to find everything I needed on the course website, including syllabus, calendar, expectations, example assignments, and so on. I also loved the subject matter of the course, and I found it extremely exciting and interesting.
Because it was an introductory course, it did cover a wide range of subjects, and I think that sometimes it was a little hard to see the bigger picture and fit everything together (especially when it came time to study for the midterm). However, the second half of the semester I could follow the umbrella organization a little more easily.
I felt there was a lack of sufficient support systems for the students to fall back on if they were not falling behind in understanding.

strengths are that the topics are pretty interesting and relate to the real world and your experiences. Weaknesses are that you have to pay very close attention to take very good notes because not much text is on the powerpoint slides, and sometimes the lectures can have some dry spots that make it hard to pay attention, but they do have cool real world relevance.
The tests were graded quite unfairly and bothered a lot of the students. The lectures were interested, but the setup of it was confusing when it came to studying. I never knew quite what to study.

Strength: The workload was appropriate--except for the one lecture at the beginning of the course when 6 (!!!) reading responses were due at the same time :((( But in general, there were 1-2 short pass/fail reading responses due per lecture, 1 paper, a midterm and a final. A weakness of this course was that the midterm and final were ridiculously difficult in terms of testing us on highly specific, random aspects of the readings and lectures. I wish we'd been tested on whether or not we understood the core concepts being taught instead of on little details that have nothing to do with real understanding. Also, so many of the questions were TRICK QUESTIONS that there was one on the midterm in which your performance on the question negatively predicted your performance on the exam overall and the TAs got permission to give us the point back. The lectures on the whole were super engaging and interesting though.
I think its well taught, Scholl has great pedagogy even if he is a tad full of himself at times.

Professor Scholl is an interesting yet arrogant lecturer who at times excites you about the material and at other times lets his own opinions and ego get in the way of the material at hand. The lecture style with no sections also make it easy to go through this class thinking you are fine and then doing awful on exams. The lecture slides posted are also awful for reviewing for exams and are meant to be broad so that people come to lecture but end up containing mainly one-word slides that are no help at all.

Strengths - it's just really freakin interesting. Brian Scholl is a personality himself and a really brilliant man. He's taught this class many times and has all his jokes and stuff planned out. You will be laughing your butt off during this class while learning a whole lot. I really enjoyed the class, thought that the readings were helpful and that reading responses were useful, and found the exams to be challenging yet very fair. There are a lot of resources in place to help you succeed in this class, so especially if this is your first semester at Yale, please take advantage of them. When the TFs offer to read your draft, take them up on it. Go to office hours, ask questions, go to review sessions. These things will make the difference between doing mediocre and doing great in the class.

Weaknesses - I heard that some TFs were far stricter graders than others. Luckily, mine was not one of the strict ones. Standardizing grades across TFs if possible would be very helpful. Also, sometimes Brian Scholl made a few comments that were a wee bit yikes. He described a study he read as "I'm not saying I literally had an orgasm when I read it, but I basically did" which is really awkward and also was talking about how he wore an eye tracker to class one year and then had to terminate the experiment because he was accidentally staring at girls' boobs (at least that's what he implied). Those comments were like super uncomfy, and I don't think Scholl said them out of malice at all, I think he might just genuinely not know. He's really funny and 99% of his jokes are a hit, but those 1% were a somewhat uncomfortable miss.

I do think that the course could have updated grades on Canvas because it was hard to get a reliable indication of how I was doing throughout the semester. Besides that, the grading was pretty fair and the tests seemed to test knowledge and applications of the class well.

Unlike some of the introductory level courses at Yale, this was a very accessible introductory course. The material was very well explained, in such a way that made it easy to understand. Additionally, the pace of the course was excellent: if it was evident that the class was confused or not fully understanding a concept, the instructor was very flexible about spending more time on it.
In my opinion, the only downside to the course was that there just wasn't enough time to go over everything! I would have loved to have been able to cover more material.

One note: for students who have difficulties with reading (for any number of reasons), the workload is pretty heavy due to the weekly readings, some of which are quite long. I personally would have found it helpful to have had some assistance with this, as I definitely struggled on this front. I don't know how this could be improved, but it's something to think about.

The strengths are that Brian is a very engaging teacher and he presents the material in a way that lets you know that while it is complex, the concepts nest into each other intuitively. The major weakness of this course is absolutely that Brian made several sexual comments and delivered one glaringly  sexist anecdote to the entire lecture hall, disregarding the implications and consequences that his choices have for the ability of women and nonbinary students in his class to learn. The comments of this nature repeatedly disrupted the class for these individuals.
Strengths are that it gave a broad overview of different elements of cognitive science, weaknesses are that it is difficult to tell what cognitive science would be like as a major

strength: my TA
weakness: complicated and unstructured lectures

Strengths: extremely interesting material, wonderful professor and TA, engaging lectures
Weaknesses: large lecture does not allow for much individual attention in terms of questions or discussion

One strength of this class lies in the fact that the class was engaging and interesting. The material was presented in such a way that made it quite memorable. One weakness of the course was that very little information about the midterm was provided, making some students uncomfortable and unable to decide how to truly prepare. It would also have been nice to be informed of which of the many articles that were assigned would be tested on, as not all articles were explicitly discussed during lecture. In addition, Professor Scholl stated during the first few lectures that lecture slides would most often be posted on the class website prior to lecture, but failed to follow through on this promise. Posting the lecture slides would have helped in note-taking and kept the students from taking unnecessary notes and, instead, focus on taking in and absorbing the new information.
Very interesting but the course is very ambiguous so you never really understand what information is supposed to be important and what is just conversation.

Strengths: You learn some interesting facts about the mind. The lecturers are usually good; some are more engaging than others.
Weaknesses: The class feels all over the place because of all the content we cover. Brian Scholl really hypes up the class during shopping period, but the intrigue wore off a little as the semester went on.

Some of the strengths of this course regard the pacing and workload of the course. A different topic is basically covered each day, with the readings taking up no more than a few hours of the week. A weakness of the course however revolves around feedback, as it is a large lecture class thought in a manner where it tries to mimic a seminar.

Strengths: lectures were really thorough and engaging, readings were directly related and helpful

Weaknesses: final paper was a bit confusing to write given the vague topic, some lectures were confusing and scattered
Huge lecture and tests were hard but lecture was awesome and interesting

This course was very engaging in class. However, sometimes the professor spoke very quickly and if you missed one of his comments, they would not be on the slides (the slides were almost empty). So it's just really important to be laser focused in class more so than any other class I've taken at Yale.

One strength is that the course includes a wide array of disciplines, which properly reflects the field of cognitive science. One weakness is that students are often expected to understand a nuanced topic within a discipline for the test (ex. Turning Machines from Computer Science, or Case Assignment from Linguistics). The reason this is a weakness is because those topics were used merely a metaphors for the mind, therefore a student's time is wasted memorizing methods merely to extend an already understood metaphor.

Strengths: We covered a wide array of topics.
Weaknesses: The syllabus had no cohesion. The course was not well structured, and every topic was taught at a surface level, but was expected to be known in detail by students.

The lecture content was not well prepared - the slides had too little content on them and some unnecessary digressions took up too many slides. 
It would also be best if Professor Scholl could limit discussion of his personal opinions (e.g. books on consciousness). For instance, the dismissive tone he used when addressing such topics also made it difficult to bring up contradictory opinions. I did appreciate photos/videos of his daughter, though.

I think the course is set up well, the only thing I would say is that the paper did not have a ton of instruction, and it would have been nice if we could have had a little more guidance before starting that.
It is unclear what information students are responsible for knowing. Perhaps a topic list could be released before the midterm and final to guide studying.
It was hard to prepare for tests
I think that this course is put together extremely well and should remain as is.
It's a good course, with a lot of support from the TAs
Professor does not teach well and takes pleasure in making students confused.

Strengths: it was super interesting, the readings are relatively short and interesting, the readings and lectures don't overlap much and work together well
Weaknesses: sometimes it was hard to see how everything fit together

The course could be improved by having a more clear way to let students know what material they are responsible for on the exams. At times, the course felt a little disjointed due to its nature of jumping around to many different areas of cognitive science. A study guide of listed topics may be helpful.
It was the best class Ive ever taken. The content was extremely interesting.
The lectures are interesting. It is hard to know what to expect from the midterm.
The slides for the notes were posted as blank slides even though the class went too fast to take notes.
The lectures are interesting but the are posted in an unhelpful manner without key information. Sometimes feels as if the professor wants you to struggle.
Super fun and relevant material, but some lectures were disorganized and controversial topics were treated with insufficient balance and nuance
Great lectures and fun homeworks.

This course is essentially a series of TED Talks with seemingly little to no connecting theme besides "it involves the mind". The course lacked cohesion, none of the sections built upon the last, and the result is a random splattering of knowledge about the field. There simply needs to be links between concepts, which would make the class both more comprehensible and more enjoyable.

The strength of this course were the lectures, which were always interesting and fun. In addition, the articles we read were always engaging and intriguing. However, this course could be organized slightly better. The lessons were interesting, but it was not always clear how the different ideas fit together. Perhaps if more time was spent connecting the ideas or going into more depth about a few of them, this course would be slightly more cohesive.

- interesting lectures
- lacking cohesive theme
This course was very interesting and very well-taught -- I think I got a very good introduction to the discipline of cognitive science.

I feel that providing a more well-defined set of expectations for the midterm and final as well as the paper would have contributed to more students doing well in this course.  I found myself confused about how to study for the midterm.  The only reason I had more success on the final was because of my exposure to the midterm test, not because of any resources, helpful tips, or other defined expectations provided by the instructor.  I was stressed about the final paper because although Scholl provided sample papers for viewing, the prompt itself and its requirements were so vague that I struggled to even identify a topic about which to write.  In a course where the grades of these major assignments matter so much because there are so few grade entries, I believe more clarity would heighten student engagement and success.

More relatively low-stakes assessments throughout the semester might help to clarify what knowledge we need to ascertain from large and broad lectures where there is a fair amount of information we are not expected to be tested on.

I think that the lectures were very interesting and the TF's were also extremely involved. However, I will say that the exams were a bit sporadic and didn't really test understanding over memorization.

Strengths: great lecturer, strong tfs, highly organized structure while still being very interesting. A fun lecture class! Challenging without being super hard.

Weaknesses: art gallery lecture hall is not an optimal note-taking space. There's not a very good way to prepare yourself for the tests because, well... even Brian doesn't know what's on it until the night before.

Strengths of the course comes from Professor Scholl's passion for the course and the knowledge and preparation that goes into every lecture. The class was well organized, and content was kept especially interesting every time. Weakness might be the lack of feedback, and the layout of the course grading, which made it difficult to know just how well you're doing in the class, along with the variability in TA grading and feedback.

The lectures were always very engaging and interesting but sometimes the readings were a bit excessive. I think the course could be improved if some time was devoted to highlighting the key concepts from very dense and inaccessible readings during the lectures.

Strengths: very engaging lecturer/material 

Weaknesses: sometimes material not well structured, sometimes real world application of material ambiguous
The tests are graded harshly and you can feel really good about a test and still do poorly.

Strengths: interesting, fun, interactive

Weaknesses: topics too scattered; perhaps concept review sheets or some other supplemental material might be helpful other than just research papers

The class is truly an Introduction to cognitive science. The lectures basically covered each subfield in cognitive science for a week or two, then moved on to a different subfield. This could be both a strength and a weakness, depending on what your preferences and goals are.
Strengths are that the lecturer is very well prepared and does a good job. Weaknesses are (high) variability on test material and the lack of usefulness of previous practice tests.
The strengths were the interest of the material, the weakness is that the material was broad ranging but weakly ties together; it often wasnt clear how the course was organized or why

Strengths: Incredibly entertaining and chock-full of mind-blowing examples

Weaknesses: Leaves me walking away from lectures amazed, but not entirely sure what I learned.
The course had really interesting content and a highly engaging professor. I think that it could have chosen fewer topics and gone deeper into each of them.
The amount of freedom given for our final paper proved pretty difficult. Maybe giving more direction in that sense would be better.
This course is completely disorganized and Brian is often distracted. I didn't realize this course was about photos of his daughter, his dumbass jokes, and general incompetence.
Strengths: Relatable topics that impact things we do everyday

Brian Scholl is an excellent lecturer. I thourougly enjoyed each class. I think for what it is trying to accomplish this course does its job very well. Because of the large class size and extensive topic list, it's easy to get a little lost in it, but no more than any other intro course. Reading responses are a good requirement, generally force you to do reading.

Strengths: Brian scholl. All of the lectures felt purposeful. He is engaging. Every idea flowed into the next. 

Weakness: WAYYY to large. 300 people for a class that should be taught in sections of 30. Really difficult to seek help understanding concepts not easily apparent to you (and there are plenty). The tests were overly tricky, asking for precise terminology in answers that were otherwise correct. Tests are noncumulative, but because there are no textbooks and lecture slides have barely any info, so your own notes are the only thing to help you study. Little to no guidance for the exam, which is why so many freshmen fail the midterm.

The strength is definitely the way Professor Scholl explains complex terms in an understandable and intriguing manner. The weakness would be the large size of the class, making it feel as if a giant TED talk.

I thought that this course was taught in a way that was engaging and that allowed for learning. However, I thought that the thought paper assignment was not explained in a way that made it clear what was expected of us. I would have really liked a rubric so I knew exactly how I was being graded. Despite checking in with my TA multiple times during the writing process, it appears I was still confused after passing it in, so I would have appreciated clearer guidelines for the paper.

Brian was very entertaining and the lectures were very interesting! However, I sometimes felt confused as to what I should be gaining from a lecture and what material we we were coveringthe lectures were always so interesting, yet they were very fast so sometimes I didnt get the point.
Overall good, about as well done as a giant lecture can be done.
Strengths include the breadth of the course, which is incredible. One weakness is not being able to have sections to discuss readings and process information as a group.
Course material was very interesting and very well presented, although the course seemed to lack some structure.

The strengths were that the pass/pass grading of the reading responses made the workload manageable, even though some of the readings were extremely long and go into depth not needed for the course.

No.  Regardless of whether you're looking to venture into how the mind works for the first time or are trying to fulfill the science requirement for the psychology major, you'd be better served taking a course that will provide you more feedback on your work.  Only take this course if you intend to major in cognitive science.

Absolutely! It's not too much work at all and it's a great introduction to how your own brain works. I highly highly recommend it to everyone, even if you think you have no interest in the brain (as I thought before I took this class). Prepare to have your outlook on life changed!

I would not recommend this class since the examinations often felt unfair/unnecessarily tricky and the material was so broad that it was possible to like one week of the course content and dislike every other topic. There was not much support from the professor in steering you in the right direction when studying for tests.
I definitely would! I think it's a class that people should take because it really helps you to explore your own biases and how your mind functions in an underlying way.

I would recommend this class to another student only if they are considering the cognitive science major (and even then this class may persuade them against it). Fair warning: Brian Scholl made many slightly sexist comments during his lectures.
Recommended for most students interested in psychology

I would say that this is an interesting course to take, especially for a first-year that is not sure what to major in. Because there are so many different aspects to cognitive science, this class is a good way to explore many fields. I have to say that the course did not live up to my expectations, though, as it was a mishmash of different lessons that did not really click to a satisfying conclusion.

If you have room in your schedule, take this course.  You will learn so much that you never would have learned elsewhere.  A good portion of the content was covered in Intro Psych, but here it is viewed from different areas of study.

I would recommend this course to another student, but Credit/D. It provided a lot of insight to a lot of different and relevant domains, and I think everyone can benefit from studying how the human mind works, but the grading was a little harsh.
Yes. It was interesting.

No, I would not recommend this course to other students. Professor Scholl's generally unpleasant demeanor and poor teaching style, in combination with a poor course structure make this a waste of my money and generally short time of being at Yale. While I would recommend a class to someone if it was difficult but rewarding, I cannot say that about this class. I thought that it was extremely unnecessarily hard and Professor Scholl made me feel dumb whenever I asked questions by saying that what I was asking was obvious when I know I was not the only one with such concerns. In addition I had a special circumstance during the course and he made it extremely hard for me unnecessarily and made me feel really bad about it when it was out of my control. He always acted like he was the smartest person in the world, and while I think he definitely made great contributions to psychology, this personality trait made him an extremely unpleasant teacher.

I would recommend this course to another student, but beware: there aren't many assignments to keep you in check throughout the course of the semester and it is very tempting not to review notes weekly / biweekly (or at all) until right before the exam. Overall, though, I learned a lot of interesting things: some useful, some not practical at all. I'm glad I took this course, but I am not sure if cognitive science is for me.
Yes, because the material is interesting and relevant to the inner workings of one's own mind.

Yes! Prof Scholl is hilarious while also teaching really well. You will remember things from his lectures just because of how he relates it back to the main themes of the course and also quirky aspects of every day life.
Good for STEM majors looking for an interesting/ relatively sciencey and mathy SO.
No.

I'd definitely recommend this course. It's so interesting and Brian Scholl is a great lecturer. Also, there's not a lot of work, but please study for the midterm/final- they're way harder than you think they'll be.
God no... It's a trap, just please save yourself the time. Any class but this...

This is a great class to take if looking for interesting material without a whole lot of work. The lectures are a lot of fun. If you're considering studying CogSci, definitely take this because it'll give you a good taste of the field.
Yes, it is a great intro course.
No

I would definitely recommend this course because it is super interesting. However, I would caution anyone taking it to take whatever Brian says with a grain of salt. Also if you are religious this class may be really offensive.
Yesanyone with a mind should take this class and learn about it.
I would enthusiastically recommend this to anyone even slightly interested in the topic.

Yes!! A must-take course
I would only recommend this class if you are a first year and have no idea what you want to study. This course will open new doors for you, and you can find your niche pretty easily.

Even though I had my problems with this course, I would still recommend it to because I really appreciate all that I learned in it, and I think that its really information to know for anybody, regardless of their major.
Absolutely! Though I found this course very challenging, it was equally engaging, and entertaining even. I couldnt reccomend it enough.
Yes if you are considering the major. Tests are tricky but the workload is pretty light. This course will help you decide if cogsci is for you.

Yes, the course is fascinating even for people who are not planning to major in anything related to psychology or cognitive science. The concepts are easy to grasp as long as you put the effort in and the information is quite useful as it helps us understand who we are as human beings and how we operate.
Yes, if they are truly interested in the field of cognitive science.
Yes! If you are at all interested in the mind or any of the sub disciplines of cognitive science I highly recommend that you take this class! It is incredibly fascinating and you learn so much.

Yes, if this student wants to be engaged in every lecture, deeply explore fascinating aspects of and find connections between six disciplines, understand how the mind and behavior works, then they should take this course.
I would not recommend this course as a serious letter grade course unless you need it for the major.
Yes, it is a course that will definitely change the way you think about the mind's processes.

If you would like to explore a different avenue of science this is a great course. This course did end up being a lot more work than I thought it would, however, so be aware of that. It is not a "gut" class by any means, and requires substantial studying for exams.

I would recommend this course to every first year student. The contents of this course are so interesting and not too intellectually challenging. It is crazy to learn about an aspect of the mind and then notice it working in society literally the second you leave lecture.

I would. The study of the mind is really relevant in today's world and it's interesting to learn about the mechanisms behind seemingly common (even to the point of boring) phenomena. The course itself is really interesting and keeps everyone engaged.

If you are at all intrigued by the idea of having your intuitions challenged and making the familiar strange, check this class out. I think everyone should be introduced to cognitive science because it is so important not to take things (even things we are "endowed with") for granted. Keep the overarching question of "how do we study how the mind works" in mind and you're likely to get more out of the class.
Yes definitely. It's a super interesting course and Professor Scholl is the best.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. It is accessible to students from any background and field, and, given its interdisciplinary nature, likely has relevance to students with a wide variety of interests. The material is novel as it is not a subject taught in any ordinary high school, and the course is structured so as to facilitate learning of critical thinking skills alongside the actual material.

Absolutely! It was a great class. If you are interested in pure psychology, I would take intro psych over this, because that class is more interesting in terms of a psychological study of the mind. But if you're interested in computer science or linguistics as well as psychology, take this class.

Even if your major isn't cognitive science I highly recommend taking this course. The information you learn from this class is applicable and relevant to various fields, as Brian Scholl emphasizes throughout each lecture. If you're not an auditory learner, though, be advised that the course might be tough for the first few classes until you get a hang of it. I realized that the best way to study for the exams is by talking with classmates about the topics you went over in the lectures.
Yes - everyone should take either intro psych or intro cog sci. Its a good 5th class - not too much work, pretty interesting stuff
I would recommend this course to another student because of the content, but I don't think that the course is taught especially well.

Yes, I would recommend this course because it is a nice introduction to the many dimensions of cognitive science. For the most part, lectures were engaging and interactive and the material was interesting and relevant to our lives. The course is definitely manageable in terms of work and I enjoyed my time in the class. Professor Scholl is funny and a good lecturer but sometimes he can get a bit carried away with his humor.

Yes, the field of Cognitive Science is fascinating but make sure you know what you're getting yourself into. It's not easy (many people bomb the final) and the material is very much handpicked in regards to what the professor finds interesting.
Yes, the lectures are interesting and the class is not the most taxing.
I would recommend this course to other students. It was a pleasure to be in the class. Brian's ability to speak on the content was amazing, and it was always great to listen in and learn.

I would only recommend this course to students who want to major in cognitive science. Otherwise, if you are a student who wants a taste of psychology, then just take psychology.

I highly recommend the class. Cognitive science involves several really cool subjects that I think many people find fascinating - psychology, philosophy, computer science, to name a few. The lecture is really engaging and Brian Scholl is really enthusiastic about the subject. The workload is very much doable - short reading responses due each class - and it allows you to really enjoy the class.
For those interested in cognitive science, definitely recommend. However, the class is very disorganized so beware.
Great overview of cog sci. Best lectures I have ever been in. You will like the content and the work isn't too hard

I would recommend this course to a student who is interested in gaining a cursory knowledge of the material without really going into depth on any one. Brian is an engaging lecturer, but sometimes the class as a whole suffers from being so disparate and seemingly lacking any central planning. It's not particularly difficult, but sometimes the tests are unnecessarily random and specific, creating a peculiar grading scale.

Yes, it's a great class that covers how a normal person thinks and operates in the real world. Whereas introduction to psychology covers how people are different and the corner-cases of mental life (developmental psychology, abnormal psychology, evolutionary psychology), introduction to cog sci covers how people are similar (perception, attention, attraction, rationality, etc). Also Brian Scholl is a good lecturer and every class is like a TED Talk. However, the weekly reading responses can be annoying and the exams can be hard to study for.
Yes if they want to learn a lot but possibly as a credit D or if they have an easier overall course load

I would recommend this course to any student considering the cognitive science major OR any a major in any of the areas that are a part of cognitive science such as linguistics, psychology, neuroscience, philosophy, etc. It is a great way to gain exposure to multiple disciplines.

I would only recommend the course if the student was committed to going to office hours at least once every two weeks and was willing/able to engage with the material extensively on their own time. While I loved the content of the course, the lack of organization of the lectures (in terms of discussing how concrete examples contributed to a growing knowledge of common themes) made me very frustrated at the course.

Yes, if you're interested in cognitive science or want a fun lecture class.
No, if you have a lot of other heavy workload classes that will make you neglect spending time to extract the key details to study in this one.
Absolutely. I didn't even know what cogsci was before this class, and now I'm thinking about majoring in it. I'd describe it as the perfect course for humanities kids interested in STEM.

I would recommend this course to another student if you are okay with vague assignments and tricky exams (i.e. the types of multiple-choice questions where you have to pick the *most* correct answer), or are super interested in the field of cognitive science. As a cognitive science major, I found the information in this course super interesting and many of the studies we read as well, but didn't like the structure of the course nearly at all. All in all, it definitely is an engaging lecture with lots of illusions and activities (the first half is definitely better than the second half, in my opinion), and if you're interested in CogSci as a major it's definitely worth taking.

No, I would not. While some of the material is interesting, the course is not designed to facilitate learning and a lot of what we learn is just interesting facts about various areas cognitive science rather than anything cohesive.
Yes! I enjoyed the course and I can't stop talking about a lot of the things I learned from it.
i would tell them to take it credit/fail
Yes, its extremely interesting
I would recommend this course interested in cognitive science and its real-life applications.

Only if you are willing to take it seriously. It's interesting for sure, and may give you clarity about whether or not you would like it to be your major, but there are more worthwhile classes that would be more fun to take and build up to something rather than just giving you a bunch of random knowledge.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. It's not too difficult; so long as you keep up with the readings and reading responses, come to lecture, and pay attention, I think that you will do fairly well in the class. And the material is just really interesting; there does not need to be a lot of manufactured "exciting" activities or tangential applications; every single day we are learning things that matter in our lives, and I found it really cool.

I loved this class. I learned so many interesting things, the lectures were entertaining, and the workload isn't too bad. This class should be interesting to anyone; the information is relevant to all people and helped me better understand the way we think.

I would recommend it because it is a good introduction to cognitive science and will give you a better perspective on if you want to continue studying cognitive science in some fashion, and Brian Scholl is interesting and funny in his own way.

Take this class if you want to major in Cog Sci... otherwise, it's not one of those general classes that's just fun and interesting for your life like Intro Psych... the best parts of this class were covered in Psych and the Good Life and Intro Psych. ("Fun" is not how I would describe this class, although the lectures often have cool trivia-type tidbits about our weird human minds.) It's hard in a petty way but not in a super satisfying "Oh I understand a new subject now" way. For instance, they spend a lot of time forcing you to learn how to solve Turing Machine problems (a computer science thing) to prove the point that a device (i.e. the mind) can reuse a few simple components to create myriad different outcomes. Sort of unnecessary in my opinion but my friends who are majoring in cog sci loved this course so I don't know! As a non-major, it was decent, but felt like busywork sometimes.
Yes, I think everyone should take this course. Especially if Scholl is teaching it, his pedagogy is top notch.
Yes if you are interested in how and why people think and act the way they do and if you are able to take good quick notes or know someone else in the class that is.

Yes, it's an excellent introduction to a WIDE variety of fields at Yale. Especially if you don't know what you want to study, take this class and it'll give you exposure to Cog Sci proper and all the fields that compose it - Psych, Linguistics, CS, Neuro, etc.
Yes! Please take this class, it will change your perspective and you will have cool facts and studies to tell your friends.

Meh. This class felt discombobulated because we covered so much ground. Each class feels like a TED talk, where you would learn some interesting fun facts. Yes - lectures were really interesting and fun to listen to, workload is not high but definitely helps you learn, only drawback is difficulty of getting feedback on exams and papers.

I would recommend this course to another student because it was truly one of the most interesting and exciting intro classes I have taken at Yale. It has made me want to study more cognitive science as a result!
